title: (ARCHIVED) Meet JIRA Software: The #1 software development tool used by agile teams

json.text: Hello everyone, and welcome  to the webinar Meet JIRA Software.

and I'm the Senior Product  Marketing Manager for JIRA Software.
I'm joined by Jason Wong, JIRA Software's Principal Product Manager.
We're thrilled that you joined us today
and can't wait to tell you more about JIRA Software.
JIRA's first purpose-built experience just for software teams.
Over the next 25 minutes,  we'll be introducing you to JIRA Software

track and release world-class software  faster than ever.

and JIRA Agile will be sunset, moving forward.

That is a new thing  that we launched recently,

(Jason) The questions here about
whether you can turn off  agile functionality in JIRA Software,
in the case you may not be doing  agile software development.
And what you'll find is again,  when you get to create a project
the options are on Scrum or Kanban.
There is also a basic  software development template,
which does not create a board by default.
You can't create one out of the fact but you'll find if you choose that option
it will look very much like a JIRA project has,
always without the board.
So it's effectively running  a software project without a board.
And what that means is  when you create that software project
you'll be able to track where your issues in that project,
and you still have the software feature.
So if you're doing software development you'll have the integration features
that we've shown around the development panel
showing up for AG Shield, [inaudible],
BitBucket or GitHub that you've connected it too
and you can use the workflow,
In fact, you can use  the Release Hub still,
but it won't be using the boards to, I guess, run things
such as Scrum and Kanban methodologies if you're not using--
if you don't want to do agile.
So software is really, I guess,  built to suit any sort of methodology,
whether that be agile or mixed methodology even if you do Waterfall.
So really we've built the product to help it work the way you want to work
so you can do that.
(Jake) We received  several questions here around--
if people are using our cloud products to JIRA and JIRA Agile in the cloud?
What does that mean for them and what do they need to do to migrate?
If you are using any of JIRA cloud or JIRA Agile cloud,
both at this point, all of your migrations should have already taken place.
So the next time you log in you already have--
you'll be using JIRA Software.
And if, of course, you have a server of the product
you'll need to upgrade it manually.
The best place to start there I think it would be the migration hub
so I'd go to www.Atlassian.com/migration.
But anyone that's using  our cloud products,
you should already be enjoying
all of the new features and functionality in JIRA Software,
and the integrated experience  that we talked about in the webinar.
We've also received a couple of questions here around JIRA Portfolio
and how to [OB] handled moving forward.
So JIRA Portfolio is not built-in to JIRA Software.
It will still exist  as a stand-alone offering.
It is built, so obviously from day one
it will continue to work  with JIRA Software
and the target audience  for JIRA Portfolio.
The JIRA portfolio team  is still software teams,
so they have a really exciting road map.
But if you have JIRA Software, it will continue to work--
your portfolio will continue to be a stand-along add on.
It will continue to integrate  with JIRA Software
just the same way you've used it as far.
No concerns there.
(Jason) I have a question here on
"how can you have one backlog from multiple teams?"
It maybe using multiple projects  in different boards.
You will find that when you create  a software board on top of a project,
you can actually change the filter that powers that board.
This is a feature that's been  in JIRA Agile for some time
and what it is, is a board  that can look across
all the different issues inside a particular JIRA instance.
So what you do here  is typically create a filter
that stance, the boards
and also the projects  that you're interested in looking
across these multiple teams.
And what that will do  is instruct the boards
to bring in all these issues  from multiple projects.
That will then,  if you look into your backlog view,
that will actually show you all the items in all those project
that are in that status that are still being in the backlogs,
so they're still in the "to do" status,
not burned into any sprints,
not moved out into "in progress" or anything.
What that will do is actually it will provide a stack rank
of all the issues in that backlog
and maintain a correct ranking even across multiple projects
on that board.
So you will find what we've researched on the global boards here with us
looking across all the projects, cross projects,
and that will allow you to see that stack rank.
Now, what happens then  is teams might've been--
still has their own boards and to focus on the project itself,
so that they can still operate in parallel on their projects and boards
and they'll see their own backlogs, with their own issues
and then they'll continue to work  in that fashion.
So that tends to be the way that we have teams looking at
wanting to have a view that cuts across multiple teams and projects.
as well as allowing each individual team to run those now.
Jake also mentioned JIRA Portfolio.
So JIRA Portfolio is designed  to help manage the cross projects
and what it will do over and above what you can do
with the boards that I've just mentioned across projects,
the global boards that run across  multiple projects.
JIRA Portfolio--it will give you  a more visualized view
of your relations in terms of it looking like a road map.
It will also highlight dependencies that you may have
between strings of [inaudible] teams across different projects,
and it also brings in an ability to do capacity planning
so you can note down who is available, what time, their skills and stuff as well.
So if you're doing work  across multiple teams and projects
I'd recommend you try JIRA Portfolio and add that to JIRA Software
which will continue to help  the individual teams
to get their worked done and shipped.
(Jake) Looks like there's quite a bit  of discussion here
and questions surrounding JIRA Core.
So just to give a bit of background for those of you
who might have not heard last week with the launch of JIRA Software
we also introduced a new product called JIRA Core
which is a version of JIRA
that we built specifically  for business teams
and business processes.
The feedback we are getting  and have been getting for quite some time
was that a lot of business teams: so that'll be legal, finance, HR
had adopted JIRA,
but because so much of JIRA  was built for--
the core of it's DNA  was in software development,
there were a lot of terminology, a lot of features,
and a lot of things within the product
that business teams simply didn't need.
So with the introduction of JIRA Software, we also launched JIRA Core
which is a streamlined version specifically for business teams.
There's a lot of questions here around  as you're upgrading to JIRA Software
how does JIRA Core fit in to that?
JIRA Core, the way to think about it
is JIRA Core is bundled  with JIRA Software.
So if you buy JIRA Software,  JIRA Core comes with it,
and you can define within your license,
if there are certain teams that want
the use of JIRA Core  for business processes
that's already included in the cost of JIRA Software.
However, it's also true  that JIRA Core can exist independently
as a stand-along product.
So if you do just want  to purchase JIRA Core for one team
or for somewhere in your organization, you can do that as well.
But if you have JIRA Software,
all the functionality of JIRA Core is built-in and comes with it
and you can give certain teams access to just the JIRA Core features
and functionality that they need to do their business processes.
Thanks to the questions around that.
(Jason) There's a question here about whether BitBucket is stashing them.
That is [inaudible]
from some of the screens that we took before launch.
But yes, you will find that stash  is [inaudible] BitBucket server.

and the reason we wanted to roll that out so early

So there were several iterations to that we released.
Quite a lot of feedback on it.
We built the sidebar which is consistent  across all JIRA products.
So if you have JIRA Core, JIRA Software, JIRA Service Desk,
that sidebar is now consistent.
It's just much more tailored to what that team may need
so that's sort of consistent across all the products.
And we've done a ton of testing on that.
So the biggest change  you're going to notice in JIRA Software

In terms of actual new features and functionality beyond that,
there's nothing with JIRA Software besides the addition

On top of that, we didn't have time and we wanted to get this out

The good news however
is now that JIRA Software  is a stand-alone product
all the Agile functionality is built right into one core experience.

So if you have JIRA Software,
we know that you're using it  for software development,
we know our audience very well.
And moving forward,  we can release things,
new features for software teams  very quickly,
which is super exciting for us and hopefully for you guys as well.
(Jason) There's a question here about where the estimates can be added to items
that are in an active sprint, and whether they'll show in reports now.
You can do it, but we-- it sort of semi-locked down,
that we do discourage it, mainly around, I guess,
the start of the sprint being--
that the point where  you look at your estimates
and decide what to take in to that sprint,
and we sort of discourage that happening in midprint
because then you still lose that bearing,
the bearing between what you thought you can achieve in the sprint
and what you actually did.
We recommend that you not do that.
Let the [inaudible] roll
and what you'll find  at the end of the sprint
you can look at what your velocity is
and from that use that gauge to then go create with some--
do it over a commit or under commit.
and have over several sprints of the teams will get better estimating
rather than correcting them midway [so to sprint].
But yes, if you do change them you can do that midway through.
Again, we recommend
that you work the way  you want to as a team
rather than following specifically  what's built in there as default.
But if you do, make sure again that the team's aware
of how you want to handle estimates, for example,
and that we do allowed it in that midst sprint.

That includes all the features that any software team would need,

(Jake) There are a whole series  of questions here around Release Hub.
First of all, we made changes to it.
Secondly, a little bit more about it, what is it?
We mentioned it obviously several times within the webinar,
so happy to chat about Release Hub a bit.
I would say, first of all, that Release Hub is definitely,
as we pointed out in the webinar,
we see it kind of move to towards more and more,
people wanting to release  more and more frequently,
which is one of the main reasons
why we built Release Hub in the first place.
Release Hub will exist  within the new JIRA Software experience
on the sidebar there if you go to Releases
And the idea of Release Hub, what it is,
what we want to do is put one dashboard into JIRA
that pull all the relevant information for your upcoming version launch
into one place.
And the idea being that we were hearing from a lot of customers
and anyone's that released any software,
the majority of the audience here, I'm sure,
knows that the run up to the release, usually the week before,
the couple of nights before  are really stressful
because you're constantly, you need to do all your checks
and make sure that everything that you're pushing out
isn't going to break anything, it's ready for production servers.
They really wanted to help  solve that problem
and that's what we try to do, that's what we did with Release Hub.
So Release Hub pulls in,
it sort of talks to all the developer tools
that your team is using.
It talks to your CI, your CI server,
it reaches into your source code
and it actually looks at-- as you're going through
have the tickets  that at being marked as "Done",
have they've gone to  the proper review process,
anything that you've pushed out is it breaking any builds,
and it gives you an up-to-date warnings around those things
throughout the entire process of building.
Hopefully the couple of nights before in the week before you actually launch
it's not complete craziness.
You can be sure  that whatever you're pushing out
is ready for production servers
and ready for your end-users.
So Release Hub was built obviously into JIRA Software.
We think it's a really, really key  and important feature.
As I mentioned again in the webinar,
we've seen the highest adoption of any feature
we've ever launched with Release Hub,
There's no new functionality for it at this point
with the launch of JIRA Software.
However, as I mentioned before,
now that we have JIRA Software as a stand-alone product,
we can release things  for the software audience much faster.
We definitely have  a very exciting road map for Release Hub.
We've got a lot of things planned for it, so please stay tuned.
If you haven't tried using it, please try it in JIRA Software,
we think it's fantastic.
Of course, the main benefit is,  you can hook it in
with the developer tools you are using in your stacks.
Again, you can find Release Hub
within the left sidebar  in the "Release" section,
and if you want more information you can go to Atlassian.com, Release Hub
and there's more information
on the features and functionality of Release Hub there.
But thanks for your questions about that.
(Jason) I'll take on  a related question here
about whether or how would you recommend using the Release Hub
for teams who practice  continuous deployment?
And you probably  would have picked up there

where you do a targeted version and put your issues into that version,
and then you go through that process
of seeing how many  are still in progress and done.
And then looking at that done section

For continuous deployment,
it's really about  how the version is tagged to that--
how the issue is tagged to that, actually version,
so you're doing it  a little bit more "just in time"
than I guess other-- more crucial practice
where you're planning the version way ahead of time.
It can still be used  in continuous deployment.
I guess the tagging would come probably more "just in time".
You'd go through and [inaudible]
all these issues here are going to go out
and I guess your tag is probably going to be less
of a distinct version as we've put in demo data,

maybe more of that timestamped names of the versions.

there were places where there was--
JIRA Agile very much felt like an add-on and it was disjointed.
We've really gone a great length in JIRA Software to fix that,
that all of your projects sits  at the center of what you're doing
and everything's one click away,
and it's a much more intuitive,
better experience for software development from end to end.
We hope that  you obviously find that as well
and if you don't,  please give us feedback on that.
But that's really what we try to do in JIRA Software.
(Jason) I've got a question here
to whether Release is only available in Software
and or whether or whether or not in other JIRA projects?
That's correct.
You only see Releases column in JIRA Software projects.
What you will find in other JIRA projects to have those versions.
You will find that all JIRA projects have versions.
So when you create JIRA Core project,
you will see in the sidebar  a different icon, looks like a box,
and when you click on that,  it will take you to--
On the first page, when you click on that
it is the same as the Releases
first click on the Release.
When you click into the actual version on a JIRA Core project,
you might go through to the Release Hub which is only available in JIRA Software.
What's happening there, versions are really
a way to bundle up issues into
and declare some sort  of synchronization point.
So for versions in software
that might be a particular version that's being released.
And for JIRA Core business project,
that version represents things like master,
and things that's being synchronized at one point.
JIRA Software then builds on the notion that we're targeting a version
or synchronization point
that will the issues come in for release
which could also be  in a continuous deployment pattern,
as I have mentioned before.
And what software does, moves it from just being...
okay, here's a target of a set of things that we plan to do.
And what we've done  with naming the releases
and Release Hub has moved that into the next phase,
which is, for a version,  it's really got get out into the world
and shipped into the customer's hands, so we get that feedback.
So when you get a software approved that's why it's called a "release."
It's very much looking more now how do you get that--
that all those issues planned in that version actually shipped.
So you'll find features there
where we grab all those issues and versions,
check it with development tools
to really give you that release ready,
that view of release readiness.
Are all these Done issues  actually merged?
Are they running?  Are the test passing or failing?
If you link them with [inaudible]
and for the [inaudible] you also know if it's really stuck in there as well
which then helps you go through  that release process.
I mean if you buy it, connect it with that
or it actually will run build for you  as well and deploy it.
So that's the difference between Releases and Release Hub
on JIRA Software projects
and on JIRA Core,  JIRA Business projects versions.
